title.narrative: WWF regionalt program för västra Balkan, fas 2
WWF, Protected Areas for Nature and People II, 2019-2022

description.narrative:
I september 2015 beslutade Sida om en ny insats med Världsnaturfonden WWF Sweden: Protected Areas for Nature and People 2015-2019, som implementerades tillsammans med WWF Adria. Denna insats är en uppföljning av programmets första fas. Titeln för projektet är: Protected Areas for Nature and People II 2019-2022.
Det övergripande syftet är att säkerställa effektiv implementering av regelverk kopplat till naturskyddade områden. Insatsen behandlar två breda frågor - genomförandet av förordningar kopplade till naturskyddade områden och att visa fördelarna med naturskyddade områden för allmänheten. Projektet är regionalt och kommer att genomföras i Albanien, Bosnien och Herzegovina (BiH), Kosovo, Montenegro, Serbien och norra Makedonien.
Insatsen förväntas adressera hanteringen av naturskyddade områden och hur lokalbefolkningen med särskilt fokus på kvinnor kan delta i beslutsprocesserna kopplat till förvaltningen av naturskyddade områden på Västra Balkan. Insatsen förväntas även bidra till kapacitetsutveckling av civilsamhällesaktörer som arbetar med miljö/klimat på Västra Balkan.
Insatsen är i linje med den svenska reformstrategin för Östeuropa och Västra Balkan genom att bidra i bredare termer till EU-reformen och specifikt till resultatområde 3: Förstärkt miljöansvar bland allmänheten, näringslivet och det civila samhället och Resultatet med fokus på att partnerländerna ökar efterlevnaden av EU: s förordningar och internationella avtal om miljö, klimat och energi. Insatsen förutses också att bidra till resultatområde 2 genom arbetet med ökat deltagande i förvaltning och ansvarsutkrävande beträffande ohållbar förvaltning av skyddade områden.

In September 2015, Sida approved a proposal from Världsnaturfonden WWF Sweden, to implement a programme called Protected Areas for Nature and People (PA4NP) together with WWF Adria. This contribution is a follow up to the first phase of the program. The title for this contribution is: Protected Areas for Nature and People II 2019-2022.
The overarching aim is to ensure effective and financially viable Protected Areas (PA) supported through community and CSO inclusive engagement. The contribution addresses two broad issues – the effectiveness in the implementation of regulations linked to PAs and showcasing benefits of PA to the general public. The project is regional and will be implemented in Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), Kosovo, Montenegro, Serbia, and North Macedonia.
The contribution is expected to address how protected areas can be better managed and how to enable participation of local people with a specific focus on women in the decision making processes connected to management of protected areas in Western Balkan. Moreover WWF is planning to use the project to mobilise civil society and provide platforms (within and between countries) for actors including community groups to share views on management of protected areas. The suggested contribution will employ a range of different methods to reconcile diverging views connected with the mismanagement of protected areas.
This contribution is in line with the Swedish Reform Strategy for Eastern Europe and Western Balkan by contributing in broader terms to the EU reform and specifically to result area 3 targeting the results: Enhanced environmental responsibility among the general public, the business sector and civil society and the result on Partner countries increase compliance with EU regulations and international agreements on the environment, climate and energy. It is also envisioned that the contribution by focusing on assessing public administration and accountability regarding protected area management and means to combat illegal activities in protected areas will contribute to result area 2.

Preserve biodiversity in the Western Balkans and secure well-being for all current and future generations. Objective 1: Improved and/or better implementation of national policies for management of protected areas, biodiversity conservation and climate adaptation and through advocacy and national civil society organisation platforms. Objective 2: Raised awareness on biodiversity and active citizenship amongst public and decision-makers through educational programmes. Objective 3: Decision-makers are held accountable for their actions or in-actions in relation to nature through engaged civil society and media. Objective 4: Opportunities for sustainable development in and around protected areas among local community members, with a special attention given to inclusion of underrepresented groups such as youth women, elderly and ethnic minorities. Objective 5. Increased community participation, emphasizing gender equality. The contribution will address how protected areas can be better managed and on how local communities can participate in the decision making processes connected to management of protected areas, PA, in Western Balkan. The contribution will target regional, national and local level. By spreading knowledge about the economic and social values of biodiversity, as well as the importance for climate adaptation and mitigation, the ambition is to obtain better protection for and management of protected areas. Regional and national platforms will be used to address gaps in policy framework linked to management of PA involving key actors from civil society and authorities. WWF will empower PA staff and the local school to collaborate on joint education projects. This will be done in Serbia, Montenegro and BiH. The first approach is to ensure that PA management develop education programmes for their staff, the second to ensure that schoolteachers are trained in education for sustainable development within a program that brings together students teachers and PA staff to learn together. The third approach is to engage relevant decision-makers in the ministries of the educational sector to promote education in sustainable development. WWF will continue to build capacity of civil society organisations in the Region. Small grants will be provided for specified activities. WWF also seeks to raise awareness about corruption and environmental crimes by empowering civil society and media in their roles as a watchdogs.

participating-org.narrative: WWF/World Wide Fund for Nature, Sweden
WWF/World Wide Fund for Nature, Sweden

tag.narrative: 15.1 - By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.

15.1 - Till 2020 bevara, återställa och hållbart använda ekosystem på land och i sötvatten och deras ekosystemtjänster, särskilt skogar, våtmarker, berg och torra områden, i enlighet med de skyldigheter som anges i internationella överenskommelser.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.
15.5 - Take urgent and significant action to reduce the degradation of natural habitats, halt the loss of biodiversity and, by 2020, protect and prevent the extinction of threatened species.

15.5 - Vidta omedelbara och betydande åtgärder för att minska förstörelsen av naturliga livsmiljöer, hejda förlusten av biologisk mångfald och senast 2020 skydda och förebygga utrotning av hotade arter.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

17.9 - Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the Sustainable Development Goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.

17.9 - Öka det internationella stödet för genomförande av effektiv och riktad kapacitetsuppbyggnad i utvecklingsländerna till stöd för nationella planer för att genomföra alla målen för hållbar utveckling, inklusive genom samarbete nord–syd och syd–syd samt trepartssamarbete.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.

title.narrative: Signed agreement between Sida and WWF - PA4NP II
Decision on contribution WWF PA4NP II
Transfer of ownership of assets form

description.narrative:
Progress to date include (yet does not limit to) the following:
Objective 1: WWF has continued to support systematic monitoring of the national accession processes through the mechanism of CSO shadow reporting in the field of environment and climate change. In Bosnia & Hertzegovina, North Macedonia (MKD) and Serbia, WWF has supported and has been directly involved in drafting of shadow reports published in 2020 and 2021. The reports provide assessments of policy developments (EU Acquis transposition) and level of implementation of environmental policies on the national level; as such they have proven to be valuable resources for CSOs, experts, government representatives, EU institutions and all other interested stakeholders.
Practical experiences of protected area (PA) managers from all the countries in the region have been gathered, discussed, summarised and shared on the two seminars organised by the WWF and Parks Dinarides Association (PD). The report from the seminar Impact of COVID-19 Pandemics on Protected Areas in the Dinaric Region has been shared through Parks Dinarides and WWF Adria communication channels (websites and social networks) and directly sent to the selected relevant stakeholders in the region. In the second seminar held in June, PA managers shared their experience and knowledge about visitor management and their education role. Results and information gathered at the seminars were sent to the representatives of relevant institutions and used in advocacy activities related to policy developments on national levels.
Two sets of analyses were completed as part of preparation for two workshops organized in MKD. One is on the current situation of PA financing in the region, and the other is about PA management systems. The analyses were presented at two events where representatives from the relevant national authorities, PA managers, rangers, CSOs and municipalities were present. The data from the analyses stirred lively discussions and resulted in two sets of recommendations towards the Government of MKD for improvements in managing and financing of protected areas. The recommendations will be used for advocacy work in regards improvement of the legal and strategic framework for PAs in North Macedonia.
WWF and the CSO partner Qytetaret Aktive have gathered data on inappropriate practices in Mirusha Protected Landscape in Kosovo (KS), which is one of many examples on advocacy work against malpractices or corruption.
In PY2 WWF has focused its regional activities on networking of CSO platforms engaged in the accession process in the field of environment. Success of Coalition 27 in Serbia and Montenegro and targeted support from WWF have caused this mechanism to multiply in the other countries. In this way, establishment of national level CSO platforms for monitoring EU accession in the field of environment in all the WB countries was taken to a logical next step - their regional networking. In the previous year, WWF has gathered representatives from all national CSO platforms: Green 27 from Albania, Partnership 27 from Bosnia & Hertzegovina (BiH), Coalition 27 MNE and Serbia (SRB), Platform for Environment from North Macedonia and the recently initiated Coalition 27 from Kosovo.
Advocacy processes initiated and led by WWF included a large number of CSOs and initiatives (Engagement in the public discussion for amendments on the Law on nature protection, advocacy action to stop illegal amending of the Law on waters). Such actions are also used to share knowledge with CSOs, support them in their activities and to motivate them to engage in policy processes. In PY2 partnership with organizations specifically dealing with urban and spatial planning has been further improved.
PA4NP team continued to actively engage in development of national legal and strategic documents, and in development of relevant local, PA level or specific strategies and plans.
Objective 2: To define opportunities for integrating education in PAs into national education policies, analyses of the environmental education policies in BiH and SRB were conducted. For Serbia the analysis was finished in PY1, and for BiH in PY2. These analyses and stakeholder mapping are valuable tools for knowledge gathering as well as for identifying several valuable partnerships and setting a roadmap for advocacy. They have also served the work on professional development of teachers in both countries.
During PY2 data was collected for an attitude change survey, that is tracking the level of awareness/perception of biodiversity and active citizenship among participants who attend educational training programmes.
WWF expanded their work on environmental education in Pas from Serbia and BiH to Albania. During PY2, WWF Nature Academy was implemented successfully, with 10 schools from BiH and SRB becoming Ambassadors of their PAs. Due to COVID-19, the programme was adapted to an online - combined model; this was explained in detail in the PY1 report. In addition to WWF Nature Academy, work on environmental education with PAs in PY2 has focused on the development of didactic materials and tools. These tailored education materials and tools will improve the education programs of PA's as they enable experiential learning about their natural heritage and encourage active participation and reflection about the state of nature conservation and pressures that are put on nature.
PA4NP team developed and implemented a programme tailored for kindergarten teachers. Studies show that ecological identity is best developed in earliest childhood when children through play discover their closest natural environment and identify with other living beings. A handbook "Discovering the world with Livadinka Poljakov" was developed, containing the description of methods and necessary materials. This programme included four trainings in BiH and SRB with a total of 49 participants. Besides kindergarten teachers, participants at trainings were teachers, some of them working in schools dedicated to children with disabilities.
Objective 3: As an example of support to investigative journalists, the CINs research supported by WWF called Protected Areas Without Protection won the award of the Association "Center for Media Development and Analysis" for the best journalistic research on corruption in 2020/2021.
WWF and local partners have even managed to stop several environmentally destructive development/infrastructure projects in different countries, by exposing their negative impacts on biodiversity or water systems.
WWF has supported 10 organisations with small grants through the Support Program for Civil Society Organizations for Nature and Environmental Protection.
Individual capacity building plans for CSOs were developed and implemented during PY2. The objective is to empower CSOs/CBOs to participate in relevant processes by taking on advocacy action or watchdogging in relation to management and use of protected areas. WWF implemented a capacity building programme to increase understanding of the participants on human-rights based approach and gender perspective. As a part of the programme, a capacity building training was held for 33 organizations from 4 countries.
Objective 4: This objective is about raising awareness on the importance of protected areas, facilitating knowledge exchange among PA practitioners, and creating opportunities for local communities and PAs to collaborate on projects that provide mutual tangible benefits. It is implemented primarily by Parks Dinarides Association (PD), as a regional network of PA management authorities.
A three-day regional conference of PD network Protected Areas For The New Decade Challenges Ahead, was held in September 2021 in Bar (MNE) with the presence of 75 participants, PA managers from ALB, Slovenia, MKD, Croatia, KS, BiH, and MNE, as well as representatives of government agencies and CSOs. The regional conference was the first opportunity, after almost two years, for PAs managers and practitioners to meet each other in person, and discuss challenges they faced in that period.
The second cycle of the Regional Grant program for Protected Areas was launched in November 2020 and was open until January 2021. 13 project proposals were received and through the process of evaluation, 7 projects were approved with participation of 11 PAs from 6 countries. It is important to note that Sida funds have only been used to support PAs from non-EU countries. Supported grantees have until the end of 2021 to implement their projects. The main objective of the call is to build partnership and enhance the level of cooperation between protected areas and representatives of local communities based on principles of accountability, transparency and participation.
Objective 5: WWF has continued to focus on the establishment of cooperation with PAs and local community initiatives in the region to facilitate the process of establishment of new or enhance the existing stakeholder platforms.
During the spring and summer of 2021 PA4NP team has gathered different stakeholder groups in ALB, BiH, MKD and SRB as part of a process to develop criteria for the Small grants programme, helping to develop cooperation between local communities (CSOs) and PAs. Meetings were aimed at collecting information on existing challenges and problems each local community is facing in their cooperation with PAs, as well as collection of information on possibilities of good practice examples.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
